snippet: The village of Wah Thi Ka is a dust-choked, dot-on-the-map place. There's no electricity or running water. No one has a laptop. No one uses Facebook or e-mail. Sick residents sometimes die on their way to the nearest hospital because it's too far...
abstract: The village of Wah Thi Ka is a dust-choked, dot-on-the-map place. There's no electricity or running water. No one has a laptop. No one uses Facebook or e-mail. Sick residents sometimes die on their way to the nearest hospital because it's too far down a deeply rutted road. But as Thomas Fuller writes from Wah Thi Ka, the village is ground zero for a new and risky chapter in the life of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of Myanmar's democracy movement, who is transforming herself from house-arrested dissident to stump politician campaigning for a seat in Parliament.

headline.main: Election Puts Pressure on Myanmar's Most Famous Dissident
